description.narrative: the project will contribute towards the main objective of: enhancing the understanding of, and the capacity to expand, existing climate information, risk and vulnerability studies, and risk transfer options in Africa.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Stocktaking report detailing baseline state of climate risk information, vulnerability and risk studies, and use of climate risk transfer mechanisms exists.
Number of stakeholders (including but not limited to key government personnel, national experts, private financial sector representatives and other organizations) newly trained in climate risk information and climate risk transfer options by end of project, disaggregated by gender. Number of new training materials/ resources developed by end of project.
Percentage of trained stakeholders reporting uptake of new skills in utilization of climate risk information and climate risk transfer options assessment by end of project.
Status of coordinated African hub for sharing lessons learned and best practices for climate risk information and climate information services.
Number of AAI partner countries demonstrating use of the online hub by project close.
Number of convenings of a newly established south-south exchange focused on sharing experiences and best practices on climate adaptation planning and project development in Africa. Percentage of exchange participants reporting increased capacity to develop and manage adaptation projects.
Consistent coordination of programmatic and knowledge management support for AAI exists during the project timeline.
Frequency of updates to AAI website during project timeline. Number of newly created and disseminated AAI external communications materials detailing AAI activities (can include articles, blog posts, flyers, TV programmes, etc., but not including minor website updates) during project timeline.
Number of background papers developed to support State of Adaptation in Africa Report.
Status of finalized State of Adaptation in Africa Report that highlights the gaps and opportunities for enhancing adaptation in Africa and includes a business case for investing in adaptation.

comment.narrative:
Baseline information pertaining to the state of climate risk information, vulnerability and risk studies, and use of climate risk transfer mechanisms is incomplete; where consolidated it exists in many disparate platforms.
Climate adaptive regulations and risk transfer investments are rare throughout the African continent and knowledge and capacity to utilize climate risk information to develop and launch climate risk transfer options are limited.
Information on successful adaptation and relevant lessons in adaptation planning is undocumented and if documented, scattered in various hubs and organizations websites.
Limited platforms of country led, face-to-face and online spaces for sharing and exchanging lessons and successes in adaptation planning in Africa.
AAI is a limited secretariat and currently lacks the human resources to oversee the full operationalization of the initiative.
Background information relevant to a comprehensive State of Adaptation in Africa Report is limited and disaggregated. Some resources, such as a 2018 “Discussion Paper: Africa State of Adaptation Report” have identified opportunities and key case studies.
No comprehensive report exists that details the gaps and opportunities for enhancing adaptation in Africa across organizations and countries.

1 comprehensive stocktaking report completed and validated.
At least 1 (TOT 54), up to 2 (TOT 108) participants per country (54 African nations) representing decision-making stakeholders trained in climate risk information and available tools for climate risk transfer.
Newly developed training materials specific to climate risk transfer and utilization of climate risk information (one comprehensive training module for each subject – 2 in total) are readily available and shared among trained stakeholders.
Coordinated African hub for sharing good practices and lessons learned for climate risk information and climate information services exists and is in an online, publicly accessible location;
Time secured for two AAI personnel to support coordination of knowledge and capacity development activities in facilitation of project outcomes.
AAI website is updated at least once monthly during the project.
At least three new external communications materials created and disseminated per year.
At least three background papers developed to support State of Adaptation in Africa Report.
